questions.title: What is a hackathon?
questions.answer: A hackathon is an event that brings together engineers, designers, developers and anyone with good ideas into the same space for a brief, intense period of collaboration to create a game. Participants will have 12 hours to build their HTML5 game, in teams of 5 or 6, and show it off to the judges at the end the event. The best games will be awarded prizes and our sponsors will be providing something for everyone.

questions.title: What are the rules?
questions.answer: The rules are to create a compelling game using HTML5 technologies within the time frame. Games will be judged on gameplay, design, use of HTML5 technologies and *wow* factor, so make sure to be creative!

questions.title: Who can participate?
questions.answer: Anyone that is enthusiastic about making cool stuff, hacking, collaborating with others and enjoys a little competition. You do not have to be only a programmer or engineer to participate. Many different types of people are needed to make a game! If you are interested in game creation, then we recommend you sign up!

questions.title: What if I am new to programming or am not a programmer at all?
questions.answer: Thatâ€™s okay! Many skillsets are needed to make a game. Everyone is here to learn and have fun. We plan to be providing a bootcamp before the hackathon begins to teach people the basics of HTML5 game creation.

questions.title: Do I need a team or idea to sign up?
questions.answer: You do not need a team to sign up, and we are actively going to try pairing experienced and non-experienced people and evenly distribute skillsets. Having an idea is helpful, but not required. Remember, each team can only submit one project!

questions.title: What should I bring?
questions.answer: You will need a laptop and charger that you can program on. We will be providing WiFi and power cords.

questions.title: How long is a hackathon?
questions.answer: This hackathon is 12 hours with a 2 hour bootcamp prior.

questions.title: Do I have to be at the hackathon the entire time?
questions.answer: No. We actually recommend that people take breaks from their work to stretch and get refreshed, but all coding must be done on site since it is a competition.

questions.title: Is food provided?
questions.answer: Yup! We will be providing lunch, dinner, snacks and maybe even energy drinks and beers throughout the competition for participants free of charge. If you have a special dietary need (gluten-free, vegetarian, etc) or food allergy - please email us! We will be more than happy to work with you.

teamMembers.name: Blaine Bublitz
teamMembers.description: Blaine is the co-founder of Iced Dev, a Phoenix-based HTML5 and JavaScript consulting company that also creates HTML5 Games. He is dedicated to using his knowledge, experience and skillset to educate and bring together the Phoenix tech community. He can often be found at HeatSync Labs or tech meetups.

teamMembers.name: Ryan Rix
teamMembers.description: Ryan is a Phoenix-native hacker and doer of cool things. By day, he is a freelance software developer specializing in web apps with a blend of javascript-heavy frontend and Ruby on Rails and Node.js backends. At night, he works on everything from IT to Arduino-based door access control systems to high power model rockets.

teamMembers.name: Luis Montes
teamMembers.description: Luis is the other co-founder of Iced Dev. He has over a decade of experience in the software industry and has given talks on HTML5 Games and new technologies at DojoConf 2011 and user groups in Phoenix. He helps run the Phoenix Google Developer Group and enjoys improving the software scene in Arizona.
